1. The Upper Vardar Flood Risk Management Plan is completed along with priority short- and long-term flood risk mitigation investments 2. Harmonization of the existing municipal flood defense plans with the newly prepared Upper Vardar Flood Risk Management Plan is initiated 3. Priority areas are selected for the demonstration of risk-sensitive urban/development planning 4. Priority urban resilience interventions are conceptualized and designed providing basis for future investments

1. The Flood Risk Management Plan for the Upper Vardar River Basin (FRMP) was formulated in line with the requirements of the EU Floods Directive and the DRR principles according to the Sendai Framework for DRR (SFDRR). The scope of the FRMP encompasses the flow of the (Upper) Vardar River in the Polog Region, which extends throughout the Polog Valley with a length of nearly 95 km, and its 19 tributaries from both sides. A comprehensive modelling effort generated series of maps compatible with different GIS platforms, which were then used for development of different scenarios of possible future flood waves and thus support the DRR process through improved forecast, early warning, formulation of mitigation measures and emergency response plans for the entire territory of the Basin. This Plan is the single most important document informing future short-, mid- and long-term flood risk mitigation interventions, as well as mainstreaming DRR priorities into region’s development plans.
2. UNDP supported a review of the existing municipal operative flood defense plans in order to make best use of available knowledge for the needs of the FRMP. Moreover, this has created the knowledge basis for the update of all municipal flood defense plans which will harmonized with the FRMP, creating the necessary local-level planning base for coordinated flood risk mitigation action.
3. One of the priorities is to create local capacity through interactive training programs and real-life case studies for selected Polog communities for risk-based urban planning. In line with this priority, the project has already initiated activities to support the update of Municipality of Tetovo’s General Urban Plan (GUP). The GUP revision coincided greatly with the ongoing project activities creating opportunities for national-level piloting of DRR and flood risk mitigation mainstreaming into urban development. T This first-ever such effort is expected to generate valuable new knowledge that will be applied on elsewhere. Several other municipalities from Polog have already requested support in developing similar risk-based urban plans.
4. As part of the FRMP, in line with contemporary urban resilience science and practice, preliminary proposals on new urban resilience measures were introduced feeding into the design of upcoming full-size project. Priority is given to those measures that help address the growing challenge of pluvial flooding in an urban context due to the uncontrolled urbanization and conversion of natural land for different development purposes. The beneficiary municipalities (e.g., the largest urban centers such as Tetovo and Gostivar, and other municipalities facing rapid urbanization) will be supported to shift their current urban flood control practices to more contemporary management approaches by mainstreaming the concept into their urban and other development plans. The project was able to identify a number of mature measures to be implemented in the early stages. These mostly include demonstration interventions which will provide examples to be replicated in future (e.g., elements of the green infrastructure such as green roofs on selected public buildings, building permeable parking lots, flood proofing of critical infrastructure in high risk zones, stabilization of important landslides, improving discharge capacity of selected critical bridges, torrents control in places severely affected by recent floods). For all these interventions the FRMP provides sufficient level of information to move on to the design and implementation stages. Very importantly, such an approach will incentivize the ongoing resource mobilization efforts at national and local levels, raising by this the overall funding to support high-impact long-term risk mitigation successes.

As the project was launched at the end of 2017, no targets were set.

A new multi-year multi-million flood risk mitigation/DRR programme was successfully launched to instigate transformational change in managing floods in Polog – one of country’s most risk sensitive regions. As part of its preparatory stage, interdisciplinary expertise was used for the preparation of a basin-scale flood risk management plans in line with the objectives of the EU Floods Directive and DRR principles. The comprehensive data collection process provided the basis for the upcoming analysis of different management scenarios and formulation of priority mitigation actions that will inform future funding decisions of the project and the relevant authorities toward a long-term risk reduction strategy. Emphasis of analyses and planning efforts has been placed on specific vulnerabilities of different social groups so that corresponding specific protection measures help reduce the unacceptable fatalities to the lowest possible levels and address social inclusion challenges.
